channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Sweden: At Least Two Are Killed as Gunfire Erupts in Restaurant
item.description: Several people were shot and at least two died inside a restaurant in a suburb of Sweden’s second-largest city, Gothenburg, in what the police said might have been an act of gang-related violence.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Buddy Elias, Cousin of Anne Frank and Guardian of Her Legacy, Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Elias was the closest living relative of Anne Frank, and his house yielded a cache of long-forgotten letters from Anne and her family that formed the basis of a recent book.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Arthur A. Hartman, U.S. Ambassador to Soviet Union, Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Hartman, who was appointed envoy to the Soviet Union by Ronald Reagan, filled a dozen or so economic and diplomatic Foreign Service posts over four decades.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman, left, with the pianist Vladimir Horowitz in Moscow in 1986.

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Executions Are Delayed
item.description: Vice President Jusuf Kalla said Wednesday that the execution of 10 drug smugglers, nine of them foreigners, might not happen in the near future because of last-minute legal appeals.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: President Fires His Vice President
item.description: Sierra Leone’s president on Wednesday fired his vice president, who was kicked out of their political party this month over accusations of fomenting violence and trying to form a new party.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea
item.description: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: News Analysis: Obama May Find It Impossible to Mend Frayed Ties to Netanyahu
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory appears to have dashed any hopes President Obama might have had for a way out of his tumultuous and often bitter relationship with the leader.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv in March 2013.

item.title: Win in Israel Sets Netanyahu on Path to Rebuild and Redefine Government
item.description: Israelis paved the way for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to lead a right-leaning and religious coalition that could be easier to control, since his own party holds more seats now.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Tunisia Museum Attack Is Blow to Nation’s Democratic Shift
item.description: Gunmen killed 19 people in downtown Tunis, which dealt a new blow to a tourist industry that is vital to Tunisia as it struggles to consolidate its transition to democracy.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Tunisian security services officers took up a position after gunmen held hostages at the National Bardo Museum, near the country’s parliamentary buildings.

item.title: A Year After Seizing Crimea, Putin Celebrates as Ukraine Seethes
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin led an anniversary rally just outside the Kremlin walls as Russian-backed separatists in Ukraine warned that a cease-fire there was at risk of collapsing.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin at a rally Wednesday outside the Kremlin, very near where an opposition leader was killed last month.

item.title: Palestinian Leaders See Validation of Their Statehood Effort
item.description: After a recent assertion by the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, that he would never agree to a Palestinian state, the Palestinians can argue that they no longer have a negotiating partner.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian family tending their vineyard in the West Bank. After Benjamin Netanyahu’s re-election as Israel’s leader, Palestinians may curtail security coordination with Israel.

item.title: Ex-Promoter in Haiti Charged in Kidnapping Ring
item.description: A judge accused Woodley Ethéart, an associate of President Michel Martelly, of running a kidnapping ring said to have abducted 17 people, but a prosecutor said the charges should be dropped.
item.dc:creator: ANDRE PAULTRE and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Memo From Mecca: Islamic Scholars Promote Sharia as an Alternative to Extremism
item.description: The state-sanctioned conference, called “Islam and Countering Terrorism,” was an effort by the Saudi government to burnish its anti-extremist credentials and promote its religious establishment as an alternative to the savage leadership of the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: G.M. Exiting Russia, for the Most Part
item.description: The automaker will shutter its main factory and wind down sales of the Opel, but it will continue to market the Cadillac and other expensive cars.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Opel and Chevrolet cars parked by the General Motors factory outside St. Petersburg, Russia, which the automaker will shut as part of its plans to largely withdraw from the Russian market by the end of the year.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Netanyahu’s Win Is Good for Palestine
item.description: International pressure and sanctions on a right-wing government is the only thing that will change Israel’s behavior.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: YOUSEF MUNAYYER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday.

item.title: Open Source: Social Media Images of Antiterrorism Rally in Tunis
item.description: Tunisians marched hours after an assault by militants on a museum in the capital, Tunis, left at least 19 dead.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: French Parliament Debates Weight Standards for Fashion Models
item.description: The legislation would effectively set minimum weights for women and girls to work as models, a step that supporters say is necessary to combat the persistence of anorexia.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Models walked the runway at the Paris Fashion Week this month.

item.title: Pentagon Confirms Strike Killed Shabab Militant Leader in Somalia
item.description: The Defense Department said that Adan Garar, a senior member of the Shabab extremist group, had been killed in a drone strike on his vehicle last week.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Pakistan Steps Up Executions of Convicts, but One Gets Reprieve
item.description: The pace of executions has quickened, with 21 prisoners put to death this week, but the authorities postponed the hanging of one convicted when he was 14.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Surprise in Israel Election as Exit Polls Falter
item.description: Polls had showed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s party in a near tie with its chief rival, but many voters had refused to participate in surveys.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
